Date when Admiral Alvin Holsey was sworn in as commander of U.S. Southern Command, marking the start of his tenure and the beginning of key policy and operational shifts in the region.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 13-month period during which Admiral Holsey led Southern Command, encompassing key military actions, internal conflicts, and strategic debates about drug interdiction in the Caribbean.

keyTakeAways: Admiral Alvin Holsey is retiring from the U.S. Navy on December 12, 2025, one year after being sworn in as commander of U.S. Southern Command.

The U.S. military has conducted multiple controversial, legally ambiguous strikes in the Caribbean targeting drug trafficking operations, including a fifth strike off Venezuela’s coast in October 2025 that killed six people.

Tensions arose between Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth and Holsey over the speed and legality of counter-narcotics operations; Hegseth criticized Holsey’s lack of action, while Holsey expressed concerns about the legal standing of the operations.

A meeting on October 6, 2025, between Hegseth, Holsey, and Joint Chiefs Chairman Dan Caine revealed growing conflict, with Holsey offering to resign, though it was later delayed and not officially announced until weeks later.
The Pentagon’s spokesperson denied that Holsey had expressed reservations about the counter-narcotic mission, contradicting internal accounts of disagreement.
Holsey has served in the U.S. Navy for 37 years, including roles such as commander of Carrier Strike Group One and Military Deputy Commander at Southern Command.
Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has recently replaced several high-ranking military officials, signaling a broader shift in military leadership and policy direction.
The U.S. has authorized CIA operations inside Venezuela to target drug trafficking and migration flows, as stated by President Donald Trump on October 16, 2025.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Admiral Alvin Holsey, who has led U.S. Southern Command in the Caribbean since November 2024, is retiring at the end of 2025—marking one year into his tenure. His departure follows escalating tensions with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth over the pace and legality of U.S. military strikes targeting drug cartels in the Caribbean, including a recent strike off Venezuela’s coast that killed six people. Holsey expressed concerns about the legality of these operations, while Hegseth criticized his lack of urgency. A meeting on October 6, 2025, revealed Holsey's intent to resign, though it was delayed. The article also highlights President Donald Trump’s authorization of CIA operations in Venezuela to counter drug trafficking and migration, as well as U.S. Air Force B-52 flights over the region. Holsey, a 37-year veteran of the Navy with prior high-level commands, is retiring after a period of significant operational and political friction, raising questions about the legality and transparency of U.S. military actions in Latin America.
title: Commander overseeing US forces in the Caribbean to retire one year into tenure
